description: FirePOWER is the power of the next generation IPS/ firewall that runs on oneâ€™s managed devices and defense center and FireSIGHT is a passive technology that scans a network and gathers information about users, hosts and applications. Viewers will learn about Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE) and how it can be employed to secure a network. Upon completion of this series, you will be able to identify the various features of Cisco FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management Center and FirePOWER AMP. You will also be able to configure FireSIGHT policies to enforce your company's security policy to all traffic on your network.
name: FirePOWER with Advanced FireSIGHT Administration
subtitle: SSFIPS

episodes.description:
Viewers will learn about Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE)
and how it can be employed to secure a network. Upon 
completion of this series, you will be able to identify the
various features of Cisco FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management
Center and FirePOWER AMP. You will also be able to configure
FireSIGHT policies to enforce your company's security policy
to all traffic on your network.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.124 --> 00:00:07.207
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.207 --> 00:00:11.921
In this video we're gonna take a look at
the Cisco FirePower show coming up on

3
00:00:11.921 --> 00:00:12.593
ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.593 --> 00:00:15.346
Now if you haven't heard of FirePower,
it's a pretty exciting product,

5
00:00:15.346 --> 00:00:16.494
one that we're jazzed about.

6
00:00:16.494 --> 00:00:20.332
And I know I'm especially excited because
we have a special guest in the studio

7
00:00:20.332 --> 00:00:21.620
to help us with this show.

8
00:00:21.620 --> 00:00:28.165
We've got consultant, author, all around
knowledgeable Cisco guy Mr. Todd Lanlier.

9
00:00:28.165 --> 00:00:33.070
He's celebrating the release of his new
book on Cisco Sourcefire/Firepower with

10
00:00:33.070 --> 00:00:35.111
Advanced Firesight Management.

11
00:00:35.111 --> 00:00:38.308
It's quite the mouthful, but
it is quite a good read.

12
00:00:38.308 --> 00:00:40.269
We've got Todd Lanlier here in the studio,
I know I'm excited.

13
00:00:40.269 --> 00:00:41.825
Todd thank you for being with us.

14
00:00:41.825 --> 00:00:43.868
>> Fantastic, great to be here.

15
00:00:43.868 --> 00:00:47.888
We have the most exciting product that
Cisco's released in years, right.

16
00:00:47.888 --> 00:00:51.278
So Cisco bought SourceFire
a couple years ago.

17
00:00:51.278 --> 00:00:54.901
And lots of money,
they invest lots of money.

18
00:00:54.901 --> 00:01:01.671
And we're gonna see this product in pretty
much their whole range from routers.

19
00:01:01.671 --> 00:01:03.528
We certainly,
they have them on their ASA's now.

20
00:01:03.528 --> 00:01:05.664
And that's where I work mostly with them.

21
00:01:05.664 --> 00:01:06.825
But they also have the appliances.

22
00:01:06.825 --> 00:01:09.798
But we're gonna see this, they're gonna
pretty much push this out on all parts.

23
00:01:09.798 --> 00:01:12.746
Because this is such
a phenomenal security product.

24
00:01:12.746 --> 00:01:16.322
[COUGH] I wanna say right now
that I get excited about it.

25
00:01:16.322 --> 00:01:18.500
I wanna make sure you understand
I don't work for Cisco.

26
00:01:18.500 --> 00:01:19.260
I don't speak for Cisco.

27
00:01:19.260 --> 00:01:20.453
And they are not paying me.

28
00:01:20.453 --> 00:01:21.196
Boy, I wish they were.

29
00:01:21.196 --> 00:01:23.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But they are not.

30
00:01:23.260 --> 00:01:24.580
So I get excited about it.

31
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:25.410
I do a lot of consulting.

32
00:01:25.410 --> 00:01:27.210
I do a lot of training with it.

33
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:28.404
I've got other consulting jobs.

34
00:01:28.404 --> 00:01:32.340
But on the security front, this is the
most exciting product I've seen in years.

35
00:01:32.340 --> 00:01:33.832
And it works phenomenally.

36
00:01:33.832 --> 00:01:35.737
Really what it is, it's snort, right.

37
00:01:35.737 --> 00:01:39.875
So we've got the power of snort
with the intuitive gooey on top.

38
00:01:39.875 --> 00:01:41.315
Why don't we go ahead and
take a look at that.

39
00:01:41.315 --> 00:01:44.287
And I'll show you some of the power
of what we're going to go

40
00:01:44.287 --> 00:01:45.721
through in our series here.

41
00:01:45.721 --> 00:01:49.638
So nonetheless, here we are looking at
something called FireSIGHT management

42
00:01:49.638 --> 00:01:52.215
center, or
also referred to as the defense center.

43
00:01:52.215 --> 00:01:54.258
And I refer to it a lot
as on old school guy.

44
00:01:54.258 --> 00:01:58.761
But the fact is, is we're looking at here
and this isn't really a great screen.

45
00:01:58.761 --> 00:02:00.810
You don't really wanna
see this screen at work.

46
00:02:00.810 --> 00:02:03.240
Because this is a lot
of attacks occurring.

47
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:05.330
So this is a demo, and
basically it's saying.

48
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:07.100
Hey, we're attacking this constantly.

49
00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:10.330
Those red lines are my attacks,
lose my data.

50
00:02:10.330 --> 00:02:14.330
It more looked like, let me show you
a real network that I'm working on here.

51
00:02:14.330 --> 00:02:15.772
It more looked like something like this.

52
00:02:15.772 --> 00:02:20.088
Attacks, we don't have very many and
are ideas are something like this.

53
00:02:20.088 --> 00:02:22.439
In this case here because
we're doing a demo.

54
00:02:22.439 --> 00:02:23.531
We want to see a lot of attacks.

55
00:02:23.531 --> 00:02:26.180
So we can play with it and
see what's going on.

56
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:27.990
In this case here,
I'm gonna come down here.

57
00:02:27.990 --> 00:02:29.900
And I say, look I'm seeing malware.

58
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:32.669
And do you think malware
is important today, Don?

59
00:02:32.669 --> 00:02:35.548
>> I don't think so, Tom,
I mean I'm on a Mac, right.

60
00:02:35.548 --> 00:02:36.593
So I don't have malware problems, do I?

61
00:02:36.593 --> 00:02:38.520
>> No, I don't think so.

62
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:40.075
But I did see you put in
your credit card earlier.

63
00:02:40.075 --> 00:02:41.353
So you can get your files back.

64
00:02:41.353 --> 00:02:46.312
>> Absolutely, it said I was encrypted,
I didn't want that, right?

65
00:02:46.312 --> 00:02:47.636
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but

66
00:02:47.636 --> 00:02:50.790
don't you think you
should've called the FBI?

67
00:02:50.790 --> 00:02:54.473
>> Our taxpayer dollars do go to them
to help us out of situations like that.

68
00:02:54.473 --> 00:02:57.585
Are you hinting at the fact
that they don't do that?

69
00:02:57.585 --> 00:02:59.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well I don't know.

70
00:02:59.470 --> 00:03:03.313
I saw something on the news the other day,
and I was like.

71
00:03:03.313 --> 00:03:05.730
Well, I find this fascinating.

72
00:03:05.730 --> 00:03:09.800
So let's go ahead and take a look at
what the FBI thinks about malware.

73
00:03:09.800 --> 00:03:11.420
And what comes in malware?

74
00:03:11.420 --> 00:03:12.621
Something called ransomware.

75
00:03:12.621 --> 00:03:14.455
This is just a piece of it, isn't it?

76
00:03:14.455 --> 00:03:16.972
And in this ransomware,
what is the FBI saying here?

77
00:03:16.972 --> 00:03:19.549
The FBI says,
well if you read through the article.

78
00:03:19.549 --> 00:03:21.477
They say,
well if everyone just pays the ransom.

79
00:03:21.477 --> 00:03:24.710
The prices are coming down because so
many people are paying it.

80
00:03:24.710 --> 00:03:28.400
And it's easier than trying to pay,
it's less expensive than sending it out to

81
00:03:28.400 --> 00:03:31.600
a repair shop to try to
get your files back.

82
00:03:31.600 --> 00:03:35.080
So he just paid his $89.95 and
he got his files unlocked.

83
00:03:35.080 --> 00:03:37.049
We're sitting here, so
is malware important?

84
00:03:37.049 --> 00:03:37.699
Sure it is.

85
00:03:37.699 --> 00:03:40.207
Because if this happened
to you in your corporation.

86
00:03:40.207 --> 00:03:43.055
They could be charging hundreds
of thousands of dollars.

87
00:03:43.055 --> 00:03:44.290
>> And just think about,

88
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:48.010
it was just a few months ago that
Sony Pictures got involved in this.

89
00:03:48.010 --> 00:03:50.750
Where all of their
machines got locked down.

90
00:03:50.750 --> 00:03:54.556
The whole company, the motion picture side
of it was basically out of business for

91
00:03:54.556 --> 00:03:56.836
weeks before they managed
to recover from that.

92
00:03:56.836 --> 00:03:58.414
Imagine that happening to your company,
and

93
00:03:58.414 --> 00:04:00.458
the amount of money you would
lose by having that offline.

94
00:04:00.458 --> 00:04:02.368
>> Yeah.
>> Wouldn't it be nice if we could stop

95
00:04:02.368 --> 00:04:03.685
that before it even happened?

96
00:04:03.685 --> 00:04:08.653
>> And that's just a feature of this,
and it's the best product for

97
00:04:08.653 --> 00:04:10.379
malware in the world.

98
00:04:10.379 --> 00:04:13.049
So viruses and
trojans certainly might be a problem.

99
00:04:13.049 --> 00:04:15.370
But they're nothing compared
to what malware can give us.

100
00:04:15.370 --> 00:04:17.490
And malware comes in very small packages.

101
00:04:17.490 --> 00:04:19.080
And, so, I mean, they can be on apps.

102
00:04:19.080 --> 00:04:19.820
They're very, very small.

103
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:22.403
I've seen some really small ones
that I was looking at the other day.

104
00:04:22.403 --> 00:04:25.979
But nonetheless, so we can come here and
we can see malware.

105
00:04:25.979 --> 00:04:30.335
Let me go right to a screen
that shows some malware.

106
00:04:30.335 --> 00:04:32.124
Where did I put it?
Right here.

107
00:04:32.124 --> 00:04:33.447
And this is showing on this demo.

108
00:04:33.447 --> 00:04:36.466
[LAUGH] And, again, if your work looks
like this you guys got a problem.

109
00:04:36.466 --> 00:04:41.920
But nonetheless, I can come in here and
say here's my malware.

110
00:04:41.920 --> 00:04:45.670
And again we're determining the file
disposition through this product

111
00:04:45.670 --> 00:04:47.580
by sending something called an AMP cloud,

112
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:49.230
Advanced Malware Protection
cloud at CISCO.

113
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:52.152
And they basically gave us a file
disposition and they came back and

114
00:04:52.152 --> 00:04:52.731
said, hey.

115
00:04:52.731 --> 00:04:53.939
This is bad, right.

116
00:04:53.939 --> 00:04:57.120
And they're telling us this file
came back with a high fret score.

117
00:04:57.120 --> 00:05:00.153
So go ahead and click on this,
and now when we see this file and

118
00:05:00.153 --> 00:05:03.319
what this product will give us
is what's called a trajectory.

119
00:05:03.319 --> 00:05:06.431
In other words when it got into
your network, where did it go?

120
00:05:06.431 --> 00:05:07.894
So I mean,
this is just one of the features.

121
00:05:07.894 --> 00:05:12.453
I'm just scratching the surface on what
we're gonna cover in our episodes.

122
00:05:12.453 --> 00:05:16.842
And this is gonna show me where it's gone,
who it talked to.

123
00:05:16.842 --> 00:05:22.670
And the things it gives me is I'm
not gonna go through that right now.

124
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:24.025
But I'll do this in the episodes.

125
00:05:24.025 --> 00:05:27.313
And the fact is,
we'll look at the thread score and

126
00:05:27.313 --> 00:05:31.321
the report on it that came from
what's called Talos sandbox.

127
00:05:31.321 --> 00:05:33.390
Nonetheless, I can also download the file,
right.

128
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:36.423
So we can use it in our own sandbox and
so on, and stuff like that.

129
00:05:36.423 --> 00:05:38.813
But let's go back here to
give more of a big picture.

130
00:05:38.813 --> 00:05:42.400
But the idea was this,
malware's a serious issue.

131
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:45.100
This is a very serious product.

132
00:05:45.100 --> 00:05:47.430
And can other companies do a lot of this?

133
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:48.680
The other companies can.

134
00:05:48.680 --> 00:05:53.304
And, again, I'm not gonna pick on other
companies like, you got Palo Alto and

135
00:05:53.304 --> 00:05:56.766
McAfee and a lot of people use
these in their fine products.

136
00:05:56.766 --> 00:05:59.807
That's not what makes
this one sing above them.

137
00:05:59.807 --> 00:06:03.462
What makes them, this product sing
above your other products and

138
00:06:03.462 --> 00:06:06.461
I'll pick on Palo Alto in this case,
poor Palo Alto.

139
00:06:06.461 --> 00:06:08.643
Because I go out to a lot
of companies that are like.

140
00:06:08.643 --> 00:06:10.153
Why should I buy this over Palo Alto?

141
00:06:10.153 --> 00:06:12.340
Cuz that's what about we're about to buy.

142
00:06:12.340 --> 00:06:16.134
And I'll show them why, because you've
got like at least nine administrative

143
00:06:16.134 --> 00:06:19.543
interfaces with Palo Alto doing
the same thing that we're doing here.

144
00:06:19.543 --> 00:06:20.913
And it can't do it quite as well.

145
00:06:20.913 --> 00:06:24.117
Not only that, you don't have
any correlation between events.

146
00:06:24.117 --> 00:06:26.253
So now we have this single interface.

147
00:06:26.253 --> 00:06:31.447
This phenomenal, intuitive GUI that
can help us use our Snort rules to

148
00:06:31.447 --> 00:06:38.540
our advantage, stop malware, do URL
filtering, and create lots more security.

149
00:06:38.540 --> 00:06:41.220
All on one screen,
with correlation between events.

150
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:41.940
You got SEM reporting.

151
00:06:41.940 --> 00:06:43.588
That's a pretty big deal.

152
00:06:43.588 --> 00:06:47.359
So we've got all this stuff that can
occur with this one piece of management.

153
00:06:47.359 --> 00:06:50.687
And so again,
if you're looking at other products say.

154
00:06:50.687 --> 00:06:53.592
Hey, I wanna see one administrative
interface for all of these.

155
00:06:53.592 --> 00:06:55.079
I don't want this siloed approach.

156
00:06:55.079 --> 00:06:59.365
Where I have, appliance, appliance,
appliance, appliance, VPN con triggers,

157
00:06:59.365 --> 00:07:00.923
router switches and all this.

158
00:07:00.923 --> 00:07:02.964
In this case we've got our ASA.

159
00:07:02.964 --> 00:07:05.053
You, you can have an appliance as well.

160
00:07:05.053 --> 00:07:10.394
But the ASA is a phenomenal
product to run this on.

161
00:07:10.394 --> 00:07:14.088
What it does is it gives us our routing,
switching, VPN, and

162
00:07:14.088 --> 00:07:17.780
all that other stuff that we
all know that an ASA does.

163
00:07:17.780 --> 00:07:21.146
But now we have the power, or
what we call FirePOWER, right.

164
00:07:21.146 --> 00:07:24.503
So FirePOWER, the term is very
important to understand here, Don.

165
00:07:24.503 --> 00:07:26.406
Because, it's used a couple
of different ways.

166
00:07:26.406 --> 00:07:30.798
This was created by Sourcefire before
Cisco bought them and FirePOWER came up.

167
00:07:30.798 --> 00:07:34.714
And it really defines the power
of the next generation IPS,

168
00:07:34.714 --> 00:07:36.602
next generation firewall.

169
00:07:36.602 --> 00:07:38.878
>> And it just sounds cool
as a marketing term, right?

170
00:07:38.878 --> 00:07:39.481
>> It does.

171
00:07:39.481 --> 00:07:41.896
And so, I don't show it here.

172
00:07:41.896 --> 00:07:46.411
But what the FirePOWER,
where the power is all capitalized.

173
00:07:46.411 --> 00:07:47.386
I think you're gonna see that going away.

174
00:07:47.386 --> 00:07:48.756
So now that Cisco's got it.

175
00:07:48.756 --> 00:07:51.341
When you run an ASA with this product

176
00:07:51.341 --> 00:07:55.927
on it the actual term they call
it is FirePOWER module, right?

177
00:07:55.927 --> 00:07:56.937
Is that the case?
I don't know.

178
00:07:56.937 --> 00:07:58.586
I guess.

179
00:07:58.586 --> 00:08:01.267
It's really hard for
me to define all these terms.

180
00:08:01.267 --> 00:08:02.217
They seem to change a lot.

181
00:08:02.217 --> 00:08:03.890
As I was writing the book,
I just kinda gave up.

182
00:08:03.890 --> 00:08:07.474
And says, I'm gonna call the FireSIGHT
Management Center, the Defense Center and

183
00:08:07.474 --> 00:08:08.644
just kind of stick with it.

184
00:08:08.644 --> 00:08:11.569
But there's also another
term called FireSIGHT.

185
00:08:11.569 --> 00:08:13.706
This is a very powerful technology.

186
00:08:13.706 --> 00:08:16.906
So we see things like FirePOWER,
FireSIGHT and

187
00:08:16.906 --> 00:08:22.349
they had a technological definition and
now they're kind of a lot of marketing.

188
00:08:22.349 --> 00:08:23.902
So, you actually probably saw,

189
00:08:23.902 --> 00:08:26.738
it said FirePOWER with FireSIGHT
administration, right?

190
00:08:26.738 --> 00:08:27.736
What does that mean?

191
00:08:27.736 --> 00:08:32.093
The FirePOWER again is our power
of the next generation IPS.

192
00:08:32.093 --> 00:08:37.661
And the FireSIGHT is actually a passive
technology that scans our networks and

193
00:08:37.661 --> 00:08:42.228
gathers information about user's hosts and
in applications.

194
00:08:42.228 --> 00:08:43.900
It's a very powerful tool.

195
00:08:43.900 --> 00:08:45.316
I love FireSIGHT.

196
00:08:45.316 --> 00:08:47.731
And so we will go in that in
depth into these series, right?

197
00:08:47.731 --> 00:08:50.448
Into FireSIGHT and
into how FirePOWER works and all that.

198
00:08:50.448 --> 00:08:51.771
Let's take a little bit more.

199
00:08:51.771 --> 00:08:53.722
We won't spend a lot more
time in taking your time.

200
00:08:53.722 --> 00:08:57.112
But I want you guys to understand how
great this product actually is, and

201
00:08:57.112 --> 00:08:58.846
what it can do for your corporation.

202
00:08:58.846 --> 00:09:00.332
And now there's yet another term.

203
00:09:00.332 --> 00:09:03.180
So we've got, well Sourcefire, right?

204
00:09:03.180 --> 00:09:04.883
And that term is pretty much going away.

205
00:09:04.883 --> 00:09:06.601
We see it still a lot.

206
00:09:06.601 --> 00:09:08.923
But it's gonna be just Cisco, right?

207
00:09:08.923 --> 00:09:10.997
And then we've got FirePOWER.

208
00:09:10.997 --> 00:09:13.895
And that's the power again,
as I mentioned of the next generation IPS,

209
00:09:13.895 --> 00:09:15.045
next generation firewall.

210
00:09:15.045 --> 00:09:17.390
It runs on our managed devices and
our defense.

211
00:09:17.390 --> 00:09:20.630
Remember our managed devices
are in ASA with FirePOWER.

212
00:09:20.630 --> 00:09:23.603
They're already an appliance
that's running this.

213
00:09:23.603 --> 00:09:27.169
And then we get all our vents and
correlation back at the defense center,

214
00:09:27.169 --> 00:09:28.759
FireSIGHT management center.

215
00:09:28.759 --> 00:09:29.897
The newbie I showed you.

216
00:09:29.897 --> 00:09:31.963
There's another term called FireSIGHT.

217
00:09:31.963 --> 00:09:36.564
And, what this is, is a passive
technology that runs in the background.

218
00:09:36.564 --> 00:09:39.760
Gathering information on host users and
applications.

219
00:09:39.760 --> 00:09:41.320
And it connects to our eld app.

220
00:09:41.320 --> 00:09:45.260
And so now we can, so basically we can
put a name and a user to an IP address or

221
00:09:45.260 --> 00:09:45.830
something like that.

222
00:09:45.830 --> 00:09:47.990
Very cool, powerful technology and

223
00:09:47.990 --> 00:09:52.990
we'll spend a lot of time on that
when we go through the episodes.

224
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:55.300
Let me say there's yet
another term, right?

225
00:09:55.300 --> 00:09:57.570
FireAMP and who knows where
these terms are gonna end up.

226
00:09:57.570 --> 00:09:59.760
But the fact is FireAMP
advanced mail protection.

227
00:09:59.760 --> 00:10:00.440
There's two types.

228
00:10:00.440 --> 00:10:03.220
There's a network based and a host based.

229
00:10:03.220 --> 00:10:05.760
And we'll talk about that
during the episodes as well.

230
00:10:05.760 --> 00:10:07.480
Malware is a big piece of this.

231
00:10:07.480 --> 00:10:10.040
Right.
And it is a separate license.

232
00:10:10.040 --> 00:10:10.950
Right.
Everything's separate.

233
00:10:10.950 --> 00:10:12.297
Cisco figured out this.

234
00:10:12.297 --> 00:10:15.791
Hey, we're not gonna just buy this product
and give you this license forever.

235
00:10:15.791 --> 00:10:17.556
We want you to pay for
us every year, right.

236
00:10:17.556 --> 00:10:18.720
Or ever three years.

237
00:10:18.720 --> 00:10:23.420
So now let's just go back and take a look
at the power of the correlating events.

238
00:10:23.420 --> 00:10:26.897
And putting everything together
in one nice intuitive GUI, right.

239
00:10:26.897 --> 00:10:28.506
I'm gonna come down here.

240
00:10:28.506 --> 00:10:30.805
These are our top 15 attacked hosts.

241
00:10:30.805 --> 00:10:32.500
So we can get right there.

242
00:10:32.500 --> 00:10:36.250
And I can go here and, let's say that i
see this host and I know it's a problem.

243
00:10:36.250 --> 00:10:37.610
I can blacklist it from here.

244
00:10:37.610 --> 00:10:39.690
I can just right click,
blacklist, boom, done, right?

245
00:10:39.690 --> 00:10:43.400
Stuff like that adds things to,
what's called security intelligence.

246
00:10:43.400 --> 00:10:45.500
I have my whitelist, I have my blacklist.

247
00:10:45.500 --> 00:10:50.530
And I basically can add and take things
out of there and make my network safer.

248
00:10:50.530 --> 00:10:52.170
So it'd help me stop a zero-day attack.

249
00:10:52.170 --> 00:10:54.430
Now, speaking of zero-day attacks.

250
00:10:54.430 --> 00:10:56.050
This is called an indication
of compromise.

251
00:10:56.050 --> 00:10:59.528
This was the first known
product a couple years ago.

252
00:10:59.528 --> 00:11:02.593
Where an attack occurred
zero day attack occurred.

253
00:11:02.593 --> 00:11:06.320
And these indication of compromise
told me something had changed on host.

254
00:11:06.320 --> 00:11:09.507
So we kind of bench marked these hosts and
understand what's going and

255
00:11:09.507 --> 00:11:11.030
FireSIGHT is paying attention.

256
00:11:11.030 --> 00:11:12.330
And then all of a sudden
something changes.

257
00:11:12.330 --> 00:11:16.180
And we're seeing this pop, pop, pop, pop,
pop of these indications of comprise.

258
00:11:16.180 --> 00:11:18.706
It kinda looked something like this,
which is pretty scary.

259
00:11:18.706 --> 00:11:23.447
And the fact is, then we were able to just
go over there and blacklist the source and

260
00:11:23.447 --> 00:11:25.043
stop that zero day attack.

261
00:11:25.043 --> 00:11:28.061
It was the first recorded stop
of a zero day attack right away.

262
00:11:28.061 --> 00:11:29.153
And I'm sure it's happening more now.

263
00:11:29.153 --> 00:11:30.825
But it was very kind of cool.

264
00:11:30.825 --> 00:11:34.721
Anyways, so nonetheless, we can look at
malware and I can drill down in here.

265
00:11:34.721 --> 00:11:37.136
Notice I can drill down
to analysis on here.

266
00:11:37.136 --> 00:11:40.433
I can go look at it and
find out the host and information.

267
00:11:40.433 --> 00:11:42.638
>> All right, now Tom.
That's all some pretty impressive stuff.

268
00:11:42.638 --> 00:11:44.990
And I know we talked before
the show a little bit.

269
00:11:44.990 --> 00:11:46.736
When something's impressive and complex.

270
00:11:46.736 --> 00:11:49.267
It's not normally designed for
small environments.

271
00:11:49.267 --> 00:11:52.420
And so who's really the target
audience for the product?

272
00:11:52.420 --> 00:11:53.990
And who's the target audience for
this show, right?

273
00:11:53.990 --> 00:11:56.640
What kind of person, and what kind
of company would be deploying this?

274
00:11:56.640 --> 00:11:58.298
>> Yeah, and that's a great question.

275
00:11:58.298 --> 00:12:02.299
And this is what Cisco was able to take,
that SourceFire was not able to do.

276
00:12:02.299 --> 00:12:08.036
And put this on even down to their SoHo
products like the smallest ASA of 55O6X.

277
00:12:08.036 --> 00:12:13.125
That's the lowest model you can get,
which is a really relatively inexpensive.

278
00:12:13.125 --> 00:12:17.213
But again, that would be real Soho,
small office, home office,

279
00:12:17.213 --> 00:12:19.554
maybe a dozen users with this on here.

280
00:12:19.554 --> 00:12:21.877
You gotta remember this is going
to add overhead to your network.

281
00:12:21.877 --> 00:12:26.855
But we can go all the way up through
the 5585 and get some serious power.

282
00:12:26.855 --> 00:12:28.713
And if you need more throughput,
and more power.

283
00:12:28.713 --> 00:12:34.070
Now we can go from Soho all the way to the
most advanced data centers in the world.

284
00:12:34.070 --> 00:12:34.710
>> Excellent.

285
00:12:34.710 --> 00:12:36.670
So, if you find yourself
in that environment,

286
00:12:36.670 --> 00:12:40.650
you're working for a company,
small, medium, large business.

287
00:12:40.650 --> 00:12:43.120
Small business you could
pull it off with the 5506's.

288
00:12:43.120 --> 00:12:45.140
That's really branch office kind
of side where we'd see that.

289
00:12:45.140 --> 00:12:48.153
>> Yeah, maybe at 5512 or 5515 or 25 or

290
00:12:48.153 --> 00:12:51.955
something like that,
again I was just Make it an analogy.

291
00:12:51.955 --> 00:12:53.929
That, hey you can go all the way down.

292
00:12:53.929 --> 00:12:57.610
And it is gonna be running on routers,
or our routers we mentioned.

293
00:12:57.610 --> 00:12:59.880
>> And it goes all the way up too.

294
00:12:59.880 --> 00:13:01.440
They've got the dedicated appliance.

295
00:13:01.440 --> 00:13:03.220
I can't remember the model number for it.

296
00:13:03.220 --> 00:13:05.030
>> Those are the 3D models.

297
00:13:05.030 --> 00:13:07.522
Yeah, so just add an extra
couple of zeros to your PO.

298
00:13:07.522 --> 00:13:09.659
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you can have that too.

299
00:13:09.659 --> 00:13:11.254
>> So
it can handle very powerful networks and

300
00:13:11.254 --> 00:13:13.965
give you a level of security you
couldn't necessarily achieve before.

301
00:13:13.965 --> 00:13:16.891
Now if that sounds exciting to you,
it should.

302
00:13:16.891 --> 00:13:17.633
It's really cool stuff.

303
00:13:17.633 --> 00:13:18.790
>> Very cool stuff.

304
00:13:18.790 --> 00:13:20.250
>> And you're in the right place.

305
00:13:20.250 --> 00:13:21.776
So stay tuned.
We've got FirePOWER

306
00:13:21.776 --> 00:13:25.117
episodes coming up where we get a chance
to see all of this in action and

307
00:13:25.117 --> 00:13:27.024
how you can use it in your environment.

308
00:13:27.024 --> 00:13:28.232
If it doesn't sound right for you.

309
00:13:28.232 --> 00:13:30.810
No big deal there, we've got plenty of
other content in the course library.

310
00:13:30.810 --> 00:13:32.434
Be sure to check that out.

311
00:13:32.434 --> 00:13:36.081
But if you're looking for FirePOWER,
stay tuned, it's coming up next.

312
00:13:36.081 --> 00:13:40.759
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces the viewers to Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE). He describes the primary components of a FirePOWER deployment and briefly demonstrates FirePOWER, the FireSIGHT Management Center and FireAMP.
episodes.title: Introduction to FirePOWER

episodes.description: This video continues the viewer's introduction to Cisco FirePOWER (formerly SourceFIRE). Todd explains some of the different Cisco devices that can run FirePOWER and does a hands-on demonstration of the Defense Center / FireSIGHT Management Center.
episodes.title: Introduction to FirePOWER Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to activate FirePOWER on a Cisco ASA that shipped with the FirePOWER module pre-installed. He also demonstrates how to upgrade a pre-existing ASA to support FirePOWER. He also describes the Cisco FirePOWER licensing model.
episodes.title: Installing FirePOWER

episodes.description: This episode begins the configuration process for enabling Cisco FirePOWER on an ASA or dedicated FirePOWER appliance. Todd explains how FirePOWER uses System Policies and Health Policies to control managed devices. He also describes some of the limitations of the FireSIGHT Management Center in larger environments.
episodes.title: System and Health Policies

episodes.description: Todd takes a step back from configuring FirePOWER to spend some time showing users how to reduce administrative effort. He demonstrates creating reusable named objects that can be called in place of manual host data.
episodes.title: Object Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains how the FireSIGHT FMC handles malware. He also demonstrates how you can create custom File Policies which can restrict data under any number of circumstances.
episodes.title: File Policies

episodes.description: Intrusion Prevention System policies are the backbone of Cisco FirePOWER. This episode demonstrates how to implement IPS policies and their components. Todd also explains the various layers of an IPS policy, how to tune the policy and adjusting rule states.
episodes.title: IPS Policies

episodes.description: This two part episode covers Access Control Policies, which are a critical piece of a FirePOWER deployment. This video covers Security Intelligence, HTTP response pages, URL filtering and tying in IPS and file policies.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies

episodes.description: This two part episode covers Access Control Policies, which are a critical piece of a FirePOWER deployment. This video covers applying an Access Control Policy to your managed devices, collecting event data, and analyzing event data once the policy is in place.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies Part 2

episodes.description: This episode walks the viewers through configuring a Network Discovery Policy and detecting network clients. Todd also demonstrates integrating with a Microsoft Active Directory and applying FireSIGHT recommendations in your IPS rules.
episodes.title: Network Discovery Policy

episodes.description: In part 2 of the Network Discovery Policy episode, Todd wraps things up by showing the FireSIGHT discovered network map. He also takes the viewers through some basic FireSIGHT analysis to see how the collected data is used.
episodes.title: Network Discovery Policy Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains how to configure user accounts within the FireSIGHT Management Center. This is particularly useful for organizations that need to expose their FirePOWER data without allowing changes.
episodes.title: User Management

episodes.description: This video covers the reporting features in the FireSIGHT Management Center. Todd demonstrates creating templates, generating reports and scheduling reports, backups and more.
episodes.title: Reporting

episodes.description: This episode walks the viewer through the security event management features of Cisco FirePOWER. Todd demonstrates the threat dashboard and each of its components, including: connection events, malware events and event trajectory.
episodes.title: Event Analysis

episodes.description: Cisco FirePOWER is built on top of the powerful open source IPS suite Snort. This episode covers the preprocessors provided by Snort and shows how FirePOWER leverages them to detect and thwart attacks.
episodes.title: Snort Preprocessors

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd explains how Correlation Policies are used to connect users and computers to security events. He demonstrates how to configure correlation rules, set alerts, and configure remediation.
episodes.title: Correlation Policies

episodes.description: In part 2 of the Correlation Policy series, Todd walks the viewers through the final configuration stages. He explains how to use and configure white lists as well as traffic profiles. He ends the episode by tying it all together into a complete Correlation Policy.
episodes.title: Correlation Policies Part 2
